Minnesota First Judicial District]] | term_start2 =1994 | term_end2 =2007 | birth_name = Mary Elizabeth Anderson | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1961|01|13}} | birth_place = [[Edina, Minnesota]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = [[Lawyer|Attorney]]
[[Judge]] | nationality = | spouse = [[Tim Pawlenty]] | children = 2{{citation needed|date=February 2017}} | alma_mater = [[Bethel University (Minnesota)|Bethel University]]
[[University of Minnesota Law School]] | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] | religion = [[Evangelical Christian]]{{cite web|url=http://minnesotaindependent.com/view/vp-or-not-vp-a|title=VP or not VP: A Pawlenty pick leads McCain to 30 million evangelicals|author=Andy Birkey|publisher=Minnesota Independent|date= June 10, 2008}} | website = {{URL|http://collections.mnhs.org/governors/index.php/10004536 }} }} '''Mary Elizabeth Anderson Pawlenty''' (born January 13, 1961) is a former American [[state court (United States)|state court]] judge who served on [[Minnesota District Courts|Minnesota's First Judicial District]] from 1994 to 2007. The wife of Governor [[Tim Pawlenty]], she was [[First Ladies and Gentlemen of Minnesota|First Lady of Minnesota]] from 2003 to 2011. She previously worked as a private-practice attorney and in 2009 became director at a medical [[nonprofit organization|nonprofit]]. She has been a mediator with [http://lawgilbert.com/qualified-neutrals/mary-e-pawlenty/ Gilbert Mediation since 2007]. ==Early life and education== Mary Anderson was raised in [[Edina, Minnesota]]. In 1979, she graduated from [[Edina High School|Edina-East High School]]. In 1983, she graduated from [[Bethel University (Minnesota)|Bethel University]], earning a [[bachelor's degree]] in [[political science]], ''summa cum laude''. She received her [[Juris Doctor]], ''cum laude'', from the [[University of Minnesota Law School]]—where she met [[Tim Pawlenty]]—in 1986. ==Legal career== Following graduation, Anderson practiced law in [[Houston, Texas]] for one year. She then returned to Minnesota to marry Tim Pawlenty. They settled in [[Eagan, Minnesota]]. In 1994, Mary was appointed as a Judge of the [[District Court of Minnesota]] for [[Dakota County, Minnesota|Dakota County]] in [[Hastings, Minnesota]] by Governor [[Arne Carlson]]. She and her husband began raising their two daughters, Anna (born 1993) and Mara. ==First Lady of Minnesota== The family remained at their Eagan home instead of taking the Governor's Residence after Tim Pawlenty was elected [[Governor of Minnesota]] in 2002 due to Mary's requirement to stay in her judicial district.{{cite web|url=http://news.minnesota.publicradio.org/features/200211/06_hughesa_newgov/|title=Pawlenty sets stage for a Capitol revolution|author=Art Hughes|publisher=Minnesota Public Radio|date=November 6, 2002}} As First Lady of Minnesota, Mary Pawlenty established a web-based program that facilitated the connection between community-based organizations willing to volunteer their time and services and the families of deployed servicemen and women - an initiative that is continued by the Minnesota National Guard as a nationally recognized model for web-based and community support for military families, known as Beyond the Yellow Ribbon.{{cite web|url=http://www.148fw.ang.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123215370/|title=First ladie's military family care initiative continues|author=Amie Dahl|publisher=148th Fighter Wing|date=July 29, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160820165528/http://www.148fw.ang.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123215370%2F|archivedate=August 20, 2016|df=}} ===Leaving the judicial bench=== In January 2007, after her husband was sworn into his second term as Governor, Judge Pawlenty announced that she was leaving the bench on February 12, 2007.{{cite web|url=http://www.adrforum.com/newsroom.aspx?&itemID=1148&news=3 |title=National Arbitration Forum : Judge Mary Pawlenty Named General Counsel of the National Arbitration Forum |publisher=Adrforum.com |date=2007-01-05 |accessdate=2010-11-23}} She began work at the [[National Arbitration Forum]] shortly thereafter as its [[general counsel]] in charge of the National Arbitration Forum's legal affairs. However, she quit her position with National Arbitration Forum{{cite web |url=http://www.startribune.com/587/story/1141438.html |title=Hastings lawyer succeeds Judge Mary Pawlenty |publisher=StarTribune.com |date=2007-04-24 |accessdate=2010-11-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090109031056/http://www.startribune.com/587/story/1141438.html |archivedate=2009-01-09 |df= }} and in September, 2007 Pawlenty became a mediator with the Gilbert Mediation Center, where she assists parties in settling disputes, both before and during civil litigation.[http://wcco.com/local/mary.pawlenty.first.2.370037.html ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080518032320/http://wcco.com/local/mary.pawlenty.first.2.370037.html |date=May 18, 2008 }} From January 2009 to January 2010, she was the director of medical diplomacy at Children's HeartLink,http://www.childrensheartlink.org/|title=Children's HeartLink an international medical nonprofit.{{cite web|url=http://www.minnpost.com/politicalagenda/2008/11/20/4756/mary_pawlenty_gets_new_post_with_childrens_heartlink |title=Mary Pawlenty gets new post with Children's Heartlink |publisher=MinnPost |date=2008-11-20 |accessdate=2010-11-23}} == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080830014711/http://www.rightpundits.com/?p=1769 Mary Pawlenty biography and photos] *[https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2011/06/the-sacrifices-of-mary-pawlenty/239711/ The Sacrifices of Mary Pawlenty in ''The Atlantic''] Ministry of Higher Education |type = |logo =Coat of arms of Egypt (Official).svg |logo_width =150px |logo_caption =[[Emblem of Egypt]] |formed = {{start date and age|1961|11|9|df=yes}} |jurisdiction ={{flagicon|Egypt}} [[Egypt]] |headquarters = [[Cairo]] |chief1_name = [[Khaled Abdel Ghaffar]] |chief1_position = Minister |child1_agency = |child2_agency = |child3_agency = |website = [https://web.archive.org/web/20120814013346/http://www.egy-mhe.gov.eg/ Official website] }} The '''Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research''' is one of [[Government of Egypt|the governmental bodies]] of [[Egypt]] and part of [[Cabinet of Egypt|the cabinet]]. ==History== The ministry was established on 9 November 1961,{{cite web|title=Ministry of Higher Education|url=http://www.ipoque.com/sites/default/files/mediafiles/documents/case-study-ministry-higher-education-egypt.pdf|work=Ipoque|accessdate=20 October 2013}}{{cite web|title=Ministry of Higher Education|url=https://www.zsi.at/en/object/partner/2564|work=Centre for Social Innovation|accessdate=20 October 2013}} when university education in Egypt became free.{{cite journal|author=Mariz Tudros |title=Unity in diversity |journal=Al Ahram Weekly |date=18–24 March 1999 |volume=421 |url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/1999/421/li1.htm |accessdate=28 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140530205258/http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/1999/421/li1.htm |archivedate=30 May 2014 |df= }} Between March 2011 and June 2013 the ministry had seven different ministers.{{cite news|title=Higher education still suffering after the revolution|url=http://www.universityworldnews.com/article.php?story=20130606161959301|accessdate=20 October 2013|work=University World News|date=8 June 2013|author=Nadia El Awady}} Amr Ezzat Salama was one the ministers during this period.{{cite news|author=Mark Allen Peterson|title=Egypt's media ecology in a time of revolution|url=http://www.eurasiareview.com/10112011-egypts-media-ecology-in-a-time-of-revolution-analysis/|accessdate=7 October 2014|work=Eurasia Review|date=10 November 2011}} [[Mostafa Mussad]] served as minister of higher education from August 2012{{cite news|title=Islamist professor becomes higher education minister|url=http://www.universityworldnews.com/article.php?story=20120809105521363|accessdate=23 January 2014|work=University World News|date=9 August 2012|author=Ashraf Khaled}} to July 2013 when [[Hossam Eisa]] replaced him in the post.{{cite news|title=Egypt's interim president swears in first government|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/76619/Egypt/Politics-/BREAKING-Egypts-interim-president-is-swearing-in-f.aspx|accessdate=20 October 2013|work=Ahram Online|date=16 July 2013}} The ministry was headed by El Sayed Abdel Khalek between June 2014{{cite news|url=http://thecairopost.com/news/115224/news/breaking-new-government-swear-in|title=New government swears in|date=17 June 2014|accessdate=22 June 2014|work=Cairo Post}}{{cite news|title=Meet Egypt’s New Government|url=http://egyptianstreets.com/2014/06/17/meet-egypts-new-government/|accessdate=7 October 2014|work=Egyptian Streets|date=14 June 2014}} and September 2015. He was replaced by [[Ashraf El-Shihy]] in the post.{{cite news|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/141862/Egypt/Politics-/Egypts-Sherif-Ismail-cabinet-with--new-faces-sworn.aspx|title=Egypt's Sherif Ismail cabinet with 16 new faces sworn in by President Sisi|date=19 September 2015|accessdate=19 September 2015|work=Ahram Online}} In February 2017, Khaled Abdel Ghaffar was appointed to head the ministry.{{cite news|author=Sarah El-Sheikh|title=Parliament approves new cabinet reshuffle of nine ministries|url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2017/02/14/parliament-approves-new-cabinet-reshuffle-nine-ministries/|work=Daily News Egypt|date=14 February 2017}} ==Organization and activities== The major function of the ministry, based in [[Cairo]], is to develop, implement and monitor all the higher education-related policies.{{cite web|title=Higher education in Egypt|url=http://eacea.ec.europa.eu/tempus/participating_countries/overview/egypt_tempus_country_fiche_final.pdf|work=European Commission|accessdate=20 October 2013}} The ministry is responsible for the educational activities of the universities, both public and private, in the country. The ministry realizes this function through three executive bodies, namely the Supreme Council of Universities, the Supreme Council of Private Universities and the Supreme Council of Technical Institutions. In addition, the ministry supervises the [[Academy of the Arabic Language in Cairo|Academy of the Arabic Language]] and the National Committee of UNESCO. The ministry has international bureaus, including the Egyptian Cultural and Educational Bureau in [[Washington DC]].{{cite web|title=Message from director|url=http://www.eecous.net/|work=Egyptian Cultural and Educational Bureau|accessdate=20 October 2013}} In early 2018, the ministry with [[Minya University]], spearheaded a week-long sports event for people with disabilities. It was the first of its kind in Egypt's history, as Egypt works to integrate disabled into society.{{cite news |title=Start of First Disability Challenge |url=https://www.almasryalyoum.com/news/details/1260332 |accessdate=18 October 2018 |work=Al Masry Al Youm |date=17 February 2018}} In 2018 it was announced that Egyptian children would begin to learn English starting in Kindergarten.{{cite news |title=English language will be taught in kindergarten for the first time: Minister of education |url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/311199/Egypt/Politics-/English-language-will-be-taught-in-kindergarten-fo.aspx |accessdate=17 September 2018 |work=Ahram |date=9 September 2018}} ==See also== {{Portal|Egypt}} * [[Cabinet of Egypt]] ==References== {{Reflist|33em}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120814013346/http://www.egy-mhe.gov.eg/ Ministry of Higher Education Official website] *[http://egypt.gov.eg/english/guide/directory.aspx Egypt's Cabinet Database] {{Egyptian ministries}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ministry of Higher Education (Egypt)}} [[Category:1961 establishments in Egypt]] [[Category:Education ministries]] [[Category:Government ministries of Egypt|Higher Education]] [[Category:Ministries established in 1961]]

'''''Munckska kåren''''' (literally "the Munck corps", formally ''Stockholms luftförsvars frivilliga beredskapsförening'') was a Swedish secret [[paramilitary]] group founded by the retired [[lieutenant general]] [[Bror Munck (born 1857)|Bror Munck]] in 1927.<ref name="Ohlson2015"/> While nominally apolitical, it was founded to protect the Swedish state against "domestic enemies", implying not [[fascist]]s or [[nazi]]s, but solely left-wing radicals.<ref name="Ohlson2015"/> At its height it had about 2,000 members.<ref name="Lööw"/>
During the late 1920s leaders of the police were affected by the Red Scare, and thought they were inadequately prepared for a [[coup d'état]] similar to the [[October Revolution]]. Anti-communist rhetoric was harsh, especially during the so-called [[Swedish general election, 1928|"Cossack Election" of 1928]].<ref name="SBL"/> The plan was for its 2,000 members to have 50 rounds of ammunition each. Stockholm police chief Gustaf Hårleman managed to attain proper licenses for about 1,300 guns, while about 500 to 600 guns were smuggled in illegally from Germany.<ref name="SBL"/>
The corps was unveiled in 1931, leading to a lively debate in Swedish press.<ref name="Ohlson2015"/> [[Horst von Pflugk-Harttung]], who had facilitated the illegal smuggling of arms, was expelled in December 1931.<ref name="SvD"/> The corps disbanded the following year.<ref name="Ohlson2015"/> In 1934 Swedish law was altered to ban similar groups.<ref name="Ohlson2015"/>
==References== {{reflist|refs= *<ref name="SBL">{{cite web |url=https://sok.riksarkivet.se/sbl/Presentation.aspx?id=9542 |title=Bror O C Munck |publisher=[[Svenskt biografiskt lexikon]]}}</ref> *<ref name="Ohlson2015">{{cite book |author=Per T Ohlson |title=Svensk politik|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JHlwBgAAQBAJ&pg=PT141 |date=30 January 2015 |publisher=Svenska Historiska Media Förlag AB |isbn=978-91-7545-158-9 |pages=141}}</ref> *<ref name="Lööw">{{cite book |author=Heléne Lööw |title=Nazismen i Sverige 2000-2014 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Sp_jCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT23 |publisher=Ordfront Förlag |isbn=978-91-7441-519-3 |pages=23}}</ref> *<ref name="SvD">{{runeberg |url=http://runeberg.org/svda/1931/0088.html |chapter=Inrikespolitisk översikt |title=Svenska Dagbladets Årsbok |publisher=[[Svenska Dagbladet]] |volume=9 |page=88 |date=1932}}</ref> }} [[Category:Military units and formations established in 1927]]

The '''Olympic quota allocation system''' is a program designed to limit the number of athletes participating, and prevent a small number of countries from dominating the field of an Olympic event.<ref name="national post">{{cite news|title=Never bet against Canada in moguls: Everything you need to know about Olympic ski and snowboard (judged events)|url=http://nationalpost.com/sports/olympics/everything-you-need-to-know-about-olympic-skiing-judging-events|accessdate=6 March 2018|work=National Post|date=7 February 2018}}</ref>
==Winter Olympics== ===Freestyle skiing=== Initially freestyle skiing had two events (moguls and aerials). There were quotas brought in to limit the number of competitors (particularly from the United States and Canada), which are highly competitive in the two events. for the [[2010 Winter Olympics|2010 Olympics]] the quota system limited the competition for men and women's freestyle skiing (moguls, aerials, and ski-cross) to 180 athletes. Irrespective of international ranking, each country could only have eighteen athletes, and a maximum of ten men or ten women. With the addition of slopestyle and half-pipe in the [[2014 Winter Olympics|Sochi Olympics in 2014]] the quotas were increased to 282 total athletes, 26 per country, and 14 per gender. This resulted in countries having to limit their participation, despite having eligible athletes. For example, Canada could have sent 33 participants based on international ranking, however they were limited to 26 quota spots. For the [[2018 Winter Olympics]], the number of athletes participating remained the same, but the number of quota spots increased to a maximum of thirty per country.<ref name="national post" />
===Snowboarding=== Snowboarding has a similar quota program to freestyle skiing, with 26 spots available per country. For the 2018 Winter Olympics the only country to fill all of its quota spots was the United States.<ref name="national post" />
===Bobsleigh=== For the 2018 Winter Olympics, a maximum of 170 athletes could compete, and a maximum of three teams per event, with the host nation allotted at least one space.<ref name="NBC Bobsled">{{cite news|title=Bobsled 101: Qualifying for the 2018 Olympic Games|url=http://www.nbcolympics.com/news/bobsled-101-qualifying-2018-olympic-games|accessdate=6 March 2018|work=NBC Olympics|agency=NBC|language=en}}</ref>

{{about||other uses of Qahal and similar spellings|Kahal (disambiguation)}} The '''''Qahal''''' ({{lang-he-n|קהל}}) was a [[theocracy|theocratic]] [[organizational structure]] in [[Israelites|ancient Israelite society]] according to the [[Hebrew Bible]].<ref name="CheyneAndBlackAss">{{EncyclopaediaBiblica|article=assembly|section=Asaramel-Assyria}}</ref> In later centuries, ''Qahal'' was the name of the autonomous governments of [[Ashkenazi Jews]] until being abolished in the 1840s.<ref name="EncUkraKahal">''[[Encyclopedia of Ukraine]]'', (1989) volume 2, entry for ''Kahal''</ref>
==Etymology and meaning==
The [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] word ''qahal'', which is a close [[etymology|etymological]] relation of the name of ''Qoheleth'' ([[Ecclesiastes]]), comes from a [[Semitic root|root]] meaning "convoked [group]";<ref>''[[Strong's Exhaustive Concordance of the Bible]]'', number 6951</ref> its [[Arabic]] cognate, {{lang|ar|[[:wikt:قال|قَالَ]]}} ''qāla'', means ''to speak''.<ref name="CheyneAndBlackAss"/>
Where the Masoretic Text uses the term ''qahal'', the [[Septuagint]] usually uses the [[Koine Greek]] term ''ekklesia'', {{lang|grc|[[:wikt:ἐκκλησία|ἐκκλησία]]}},<ref name="CheyneAndBlackAss" /> which means "summoned group" (literally, "they who are called out").<ref>''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'', entry for ''ecclesiastical''</ref><ref>''[[The American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language]]'', entry for ''ecclesia''</ref> However, in one particular part of the [[Priestly Code]], the Septuagint instead uses the term {{lang|grc|[[:wikt:συναγωγή|συναγωγή]]}},<ref>[http://www.sacred-texts.com/bib/sep/num020.htm Numbers 20, LXX]</ref> literally meaning "gathering",<ref>''Oxford English Dictionary'', entry for ''synagogue''</ref> where the Masoretic Text uses ''qahal''.<ref>{{bibleverse||Numbers|20|HE}}<!--version does matter--></ref> This last term is the origin of the word "[[synagogue]]".
Thus, the usual translation of ''qahal'' is "congregation" or "assembly", although {{Hebrew|אֲסֻפּ֑וֹת}} ''asuppot'',<ref>{{Bibleverse||Ecclesiastes|12:11|}}</ref> {{Hebrew|עֲצָרָה}} ''aṣarah'',<ref>{{Bibleverse||Nehemiah|8:18|}}</ref> {{Hebrew|עֵדָה}} ''ʿedah'',<ref>{{Bibleverse||Numbers|20:11|}}</ref> {{Hebrew|מוֹעֵד}} ''moʿed'',<ref>{{Bibleverse||Numbers|16:2|}}</ref> {{Hebrew|מִקְרָא}} ''miqra'',<ref>{{Bibleverse||Isaiah|1:13|}}</ref> and {{Hebrew|סוֹד}} ''sod'',<ref>{{Bibleverse||Jeremiah|6:11|}}</ref> are also usually translated like this.<ref name="CheyneAndBlackAss" />
In particular, the Biblical text consistently distinguishes between ''ʿedah'' and ''qahal''.<ref name="CheyneAndBlackAss" /> One passage especially makes the distinction clear;<ref name="CheyneAndBlackAss" /> part of the Priestly Code discusses what to do if "the whole Israelite ['edah] commits a sin and the [qahal] is not aware of it[.]"<ref>{{bibleverse||Leviticus|4:13-14|}}</ref> Scholars conclude that the ''qahal'' must be a judicial body composed of representatives of the ''ʿedah'';<ref name="CheyneAndBlackAss" /> in some biblical passages, ''ʿedah'' is more accurately translated as "swarm".<ref name="CheyneAndBlackAss" /><ref>{{bibleverse||Judges|14:8|}}, where it refers to [[bee]]s</ref>
==Biblical exclusions== {{main|Mamzer|Eunuch}}
The [[Deuteronomic Code]] prohibits certain members of the ''ʿedah'' from taking part in the ''qahal of [[Yahweh]]''. In particular, it excludes ''[[mamzer]]s'', and men who have been forcibly emasculated.<ref name="Deu2324">Deuteronomy 23:2-4 (verses 1-3 in some English translations)</ref> The descendants of ''mamzers,'' up to the tenth generation, were also prohibited by this law code from taking part in the "congregation of Yahweh".<ref name="Deu2324" />
The Greek term {{lang|grc|σπάδωνες}} "eunuch" is usually used to refer forcibly emasculated men, but it is also used in the [[Septuagint]] to denote certain foreign political officials (resembling the meaning of "[[eunuch]]").<ref name="JewEncMarLaw">{{Jewish Encyclopedia|article=marriage laws|url=http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/view.jsp?artid=216&letter=M}}</ref> This category does not include men who were born without visible testicles (conditions including [[cryptorchidism]]), or without a visible penis (conditions including [[hermaphrodite|hermaphroditism]]).<ref name="JewEncMarLaw" /> There is dispute, even in traditional Judaism, about whether this prohibited group of men should include those who have become, at some point since their birth, emasculated as the result of a disease<ref>[[Jacob ben Asher]], ''[[Even Ha'ezer]]'', 5</ref>
No explanation of the phrase ''mamzer'' is given in the Masoretic Text, but the [[Septuagint]] translates it as "son of a prostitute" ({{lang-grc|[[:wikt:ἐκ πόρνης]]}}).<ref>[http://www.ellopos.net/elpenor/greek-texts/septuagint/chapter.asp?book=5&page=23 Deuteronomy 23:2-4, LXX]</ref> In the [[Talmud]], it is suggested that the word ''mamzer'' derives from ''mum zer'', meaning ''a strange blemish'',<ref>''[[Nashim|Kiddushin]]'', 3:12</ref><ref>''[[Yevamot]]'' 76b</ref> and thus suggesting illicit parentage in some sense. There are differing opinions in the Talmud as to what this consists of, but the universally accepted ruling<ref>Maimonidies, ''Mishneh Torah'', Sanctity, Prohibited Relations, 15:1</ref> is that it refers to the offspring of [[adultery]] (defined as relations with a married woman) or incest, as defined in the [[Book of Leviticus]].
In the Talmud, there is fierce dispute about whether or not the term ''mamzer'' included a child who had a Jewish mother, and a father who is either non-Jewish or a slave (or both);<ref>''Yevamot'' 23a</ref><ref>''Yevamot'' 45a</ref> although the Talmud eventually concludes that this is not the case,<ref>{{Jewish Encyclopedia|article=Bastard|url=http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/view.jsp?letter=B&artid=414}}</ref> a number of scholars now suspect that this was actually the original definition of ''mamzer''.<ref>{{EncyclopaediaBiblica|article=Mamzer|section=Machir-Mani}}</ref> [[Abraham Geiger]], a prominent Jewish scholar and rabbi of the mid 19th century, suggested that the etymological origin of ''mamzer'' might be ''ma'am zar'', which means ''belonging to a foreign people''.<ref>Abraham Geiger, ''Urschrift und Übersetzungen der Bibel in ihrer Abhängigkeit von der innern Entwicklung des Judentums'' [generally referred to in academic theology simply as ''Urschrift''] (1857), pages 54-55</ref>
The Talmud interprets the exclusion of certain people from the ''qahal'' as a prohibition against ordinary Jews marrying such people.<ref name="JewEncMarLaw" /> Additionally, the biblical reference to the "tenth generation" was interpreted, by the classical rabbis, as an [[idiom]] meaning "forever";<ref name="JewEncMarLaw" /> thus the Talmud forbids all the descendants, forever, of these people from being married to ordinary Jews.<ref name="JewEncMarLaw" />
==In Poland-Lithuania== In the 16th century, Jewish communities in the south of the [[Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth]] began to set up new qahals to administer [[tax]] collection.<ref name="EncUkraKahal"/> These had a minimum of 8 members, and in average Jewish communities had a membership of 22-35 Jews.<ref name="EncUkraKahal" /> Their [[Executive (government)|executives]] were elected by the local Jewish community, and consisted of 4 ''elders'' (Hebrew: ''zaqen'') with a further 3-5 ''honorary members'' (Hebrew: ''tuvim'').<ref name="EncUkraKahal" /> There was one qahal for each Jewish community, although smaller qahals were often made subject to larger ones.<ref name="EncUkraKahal" />
These Polish-Lithuanian qahals quickly came to be [[self-governance|politically autonomous bodies]] with major regulatory control over Jewish communities in the region;<ref name="EncUkraKahal" /> they administered commerce, hygiene, sanitation, charity, [[Jewish education]], ''[[kashrut]]'', and relations between landlords and their tenants.<ref name="EncUkraKahal" /> They provided a number of community facilities, such as a [[rabbi]],<ref>[[Joseph ben Ephraim Karo]], ''[[Shulchan Aruch]]'', "[[Choshen Mishpat]]", chapter 2</ref> a [[mikveh]] (ritual bath), and [[gemach|gemachen]] (interest-free loans). Qahals even had sufficient authority that they could arrange for individuals to be expelled from [[synagogue]]s, [[excommunication|excommunicating]] them.<ref name="EncUkraKahal" />
However, rich and powerful individuals gradually began to dominate qahals, abusing their position for their own benefit.<ref name="EncUkraKahal" /> As a result, by the 18th century, many ordinary Jews had begun to clamour for the abolition of the institution.<ref name="EncUkraKahal" /> "In 1844 they were officially abolished by the tsarist regime in Ukraine and most of the rest of the empire; they continued to exist only in the Baltic region. Afterwards, Jewish communities were given jurisdiction only over religious and charitable affairs, and occasionally over education."<ref name="EncUkraKahal" />
==Conspiracy theories== The "Kahal" exists as a theme in [[anti-Jewish]] [[conspiracy theory]] literature. The theme originated with [[Jacob Brafman]], a Russian Jew who had a falling out with [[Minsk]] kahal tax-agents and to get revenge converted to the [[Orthodox Church]], authoring polemics against the [[Talmud]] and the ''Kahal''. Brafmann authored the books ''The Local and Universal Jewish Brotherhoods'' (1868) and ''The Book of the Kahal'' (1869), where he claimed that the ''kahal'' was an international network under the control of the ''[[Alliance Israélite Universelle]]'' and had as its aim undermining Christian entrepreneurs, taking over their property and ultimately seizing power. This theory was taken up by anti-Jewish publications in Russia and was taken seriously by some Russian officials such as P. A. Cherevin and [[Nikolay Pavlovich Ignatyev]] who in the 1880s urged governor-generals of provinces to seek out a supposed "universal Jewish kahal." Brafmann's image of the "kahal" spread throughout the world, making its way to the [[United States]] by 1881 as it was translated by [[Zénaïde Alexeïevna Ragozin]] in ''[[The Century Magazine]]''. It prepared the groundwork for ''[[The Protocols of the Learned Elders of Zion]]'' and the word "Kahal" features in that text. It is also discussed in other conspiracy works such as [[Edith Starr Miller]]'s ''Occult Theocrasy'' (1933) which ties it to the [[Order of the Illuminati]].

(Faroe seats) | seats2 = {{Infobox political party/seats|1|2|hex=#C8D300}} | symbol = E | website = http://www.tjodveldi.fo/ }} {{Politics of the Faroe Islands}} '''Republic''' ({{lang-fo|Tjóðveldi}}), formerly known as the '''Republican Party''' ({{lang-fo|Tjóðveldisflokkurin}}) is a [[left-wing]] [[political party]] in the [[Faroe Islands]] committed to [[Faroese independence movement|Faroese independence]]. ==History== The party was founded in 1948 as a reaction to the islands failing to gain independence despite the outcome of the [[Faroese independence referendum, 1946|1946 independence referendum]], after which independence was subsequently declared but annulled by the Danish King. In 1998 [[Høgni Hoydal]] succeeded [[Heini O. Heinesen]] as party leader. At the [[legislative]] [[elections in the Faroe Islands|elections]], held on 20 January 2004, the party won 21.7% of the popular vote and 8 out of 33 seats. However, after the passing of an amendment adding the phrase 'sexual orientation' to paragraph 266b of the Anti-Discrimination Act, MP [[Karsten Hansen]] announced that he was leaving the party owing to a difference in opinion. He later joined the [[Centre Party (Faroe Islands)|Centre Party]]. At the elections on 19 January 2008, the party won 23.3% of the vote and 8 out of 33 seats. In 2007, the party changed its name from ''Tjóðveldisflokkurin'' to simply ''Tjóðveldi'' (i.e., from "the Republican Party" to just "Republic"). In the [[Danish parliamentary election, 2007|Danish parliamentary elections of 2007]], the party received 25.4% of the Faroese vote, thereby retaining one of the two Faroese seats in the Danish national [[Folketing]]. In [[Danish parliamentary election, 2011|the 2011 election]], however, its votes declined and it lost its seat to the [[Social Democratic Party (Faroe Islands)|Social Democrats]]. page.title: Running Start: Bringing Young Women to Politics

revision.text:
{{about|the political organisation|the educational program in Washington state|Running Start}} '''Running Start''' is a nonpartisan nonprofit that trains and inspires young women to run for office. Since its founding in 2007, Running Start has trained and inspired more than 12,500 high school, college, and young professional women. Each year, Running Start hosts at least 100 trainings around the country.
== Overview ==
Running Start focuses on research, education, and outreach. It intends to be the United States' premiere resource on young women and politics with nonpartisan, accurate data about young women candidates and their unique role in politics.
Running Start also introduces college and high school girls to the power of politics through education initiatives. These include the Young Women's Political Leadership Training, the Running Start/Walmart Star Fellowship, Campaign College, the Women to Watch Awards, and Path to Politics lunch series.
The Young Women's Political Leadership Training program introduces high school girls to politics, equips them with the skills necessary for political leadership, and inspires them to become political leaders. Young candidates and elected officials speak to the girls about what it is like to run as a young woman, how to get involved on a local level, and why they feel it is important to get more women elected. The Political Leadership Program is held in July each year. Due to the high success of this program, Running Start has developed shorter programs in major cities across the country, beginning in New York City and California.
The Running Start/Walmart Star Fellowship program, launched in September 2009, brings 14 female college students or recent graduates to Washington, DC each year to learn about politics and work on Capitol Hill for a female Member of Congress. The Fellows hone their political skills and learn about the legislative process first-hand. Each Friday, the fellows take part in a seminar conducted by Running Start which heightens their internship experience by giving them the skills and contacts they need to become political leaders. Fellows must also interview the Congresswoman they intern with.<ref>http://rapidcityjournal.com/news/article_c9d87604-5cd1-11e0-9734-001cc4c002e0.html</ref> The Fellows emerge from this semester in DC with a deeper understanding of the need for more women to run for office, and confidence in their own abilities to lead, whether at their schools or on the national stage.
Campaign College is an initiative in which Running Start, the Women and Politics Institute at American University, and the American Association of University Women work with student governments at colleges around the country to train college women on how to run for office.
The Women to Watch awards is an annual event which honors impressive young women leaders under 40. In 2009, honorees included [[Erin Burnett]], CNBC television anchor; Julie Gilbert, founder and CEO of WOLF Means Business; [[Tammy Duckworth]], Assistant Secretary of Public and Intergovernmental Affairs, Department of Veterans Affairs; [[Betsy Fischer]], Executive Producer of ''Meet the Press''; and [[Mona Sutphen]], Deputy Chief of Staff to the Obama Administration. In 2008, honorees included [[Dana Perino]], White House Press Secretary; [[Linda Rottenberg]], CEO of Endeavour; [[Ayaan Hirsi Ali]], Dutch Parliamentarian; [[Cathy Lanier]], DC Chief of Police; and [[Michelle Rhee]], DC Schools Chancellor. By honoring these outstanding women, the event inspires young women and girls to take their leadership to the next level. Proceeds from the Women to Watch Awards benefit Running Start's research and education programs. This gala event is held annually in May at the National Press Club in Washington, DC.
The Path to Politics luncheon series brings together young women interested in running for public office and gives them the opportunity to meet young women legislators and candidates over lunch. The speakers focus on a particular aspect of what it is like to run or serve as a young woman. Each seminar focuses on practical advice, such as fundraising, building one's base, working with the national parties, and establishing credibility as a young woman legislature, as well as inspiring the audience to run for office themselves.
Through these and other programs, Running Start seeks to educate young women about how they can make a difference in politics by becoming candidates themselves.
==References== {{reflist}}

'''Settler society''' is a theoretical term in early modern and modern history that describes a common link between modern, predominantly [[Europe]]an, attempts to permanently settle in other areas of the world. It is used to distinguish settler [[colonies]] from [[resource extraction]] colonies.
==See also== *[[Settler colonialism]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2014}} {{Infobox political party | country = Lithuania | name = Socialist People's Front |native_name = Socialistinis liaudies frontas |logo = File:Socialist_People's_Front_(Lithuania)_logo.png | leader = [[Giedrius Grabauskas]] | colorcode = red | foundation = 2009 | international = [[International Meeting of Communist and Workers' Parties]]
[[International Communist Seminar]] | european = [[Initiative of Communist and Workers' Parties]] |affiliation1_title=Continental affiliation |affiliation1=[[Communist Party of the Soviet Union (2001)|Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] | merger = [[Front Party]] and [[Lithuanian Socialist Party]] | position = [[Far-left]] | headquarters = Kaštonų g. 4, [[Vilnius]] | ideology = [[Democratic socialism]] (officially)
[[Communism]]
[[Marxism–Leninism]]
[[Left-wing nationalism]] | seats1_title = [[Seimas|Lithuanian parliament]] | seats1 = {{Composition bar|0|141|hex=red}} | seats2_title = [[European Parliament]] | seats2 = {{Composition bar|0|12|hex=red}} | seats3_title = Local councils | seats3 = {{Composition bar|2|1526|hex=red}} | website = [http://www.slfrontas.lt/ slfrontas.lt] }} The '''Socialist People's Front''' ('''SPF'''; {{lang-lt|Socialistinis liaudies frontas}}) is a left-wing political party in [[Lithuania]] formed out of the December 19, 2009, merger of the [[Front Party]] and [[Lithuanian Socialist Party]]. Held at [[Vilnius University]], the party's foundation featured 102 delegates. The merger was approved by an affirmative vote of 96 delegates, with three against and one abstaining. The leader of the Lithuanian Socialist Party, Giedrius Petružis, refused candidacy for chairperson of the merged party, claiming a desire to return to academic life. The leader of the Front Party, [[Algirdas Paleckis]], was unanimously chosen as the leader of the SPF.[http://www.hotcommentary.com/index.php?id=1600 Karštas komentaras: „Frontas“ ir Socialistų partija susijungė į Socialistinį liaudies frontą] The party participated in the 22nd international Communist seminar held in 2013.[http://www.icseminar.org/ICS/2013/resolutions_ao/ICS2013-Participants.pdf 22nd International Communist Seminar. The attacks on the democratic rights and freedoms in the world capitalist crisis. Strategies and actions in response. List of participants] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140312184736/http://www.icseminar.org/ICS/2013/resolutions_ao/ICS2013-Participants.pdf |date=March 12, 2014 }} ==Ideology and Political Programme== The ideology of the SPF is [[democratic socialism|democratic socialist]]. The party's by-laws and programme were ratified on at the party's founding on December 19, 2009. The party's by-laws indicate that the "Party is an inseparable part of the international leftist movement. It actively pursues the strengthening of bonds of friendship between Lithuania and other nations, fights for the continuation and strengthening of peace, and maintains contact with [[international nongovernmental organization]]s that adhere to the principles of democracy and socialism."[http://www.fronte.lt/index.php?lng=lt&action=article&id=596 Socialistinio Liaudies Fronto statutas] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722151025/http://www.fronte.lt/index.php?lng=lt&action=article&id=596 |date=July 22, 2011 }} The goals of the party include "the institution of democratic socialism in Lithuania and the strengthening of a unified public, whose members help each other." The by-laws also indicate that: {{quote|In its political action the party follows the guidelines set by a creatively developing [[Marxist]] theory and methodology, advances made by western social democracies, the positive beginnings of [[Soviet Union|soviet socialism]], the achievements of the [[capitalism|capitalist system]] beneficial to society, and the principles of humanitarianism, [[equality before the law|equal rights]], and solidarity... The SPF represents physical and intellectual work done on behalf of the interests of the workers in the private, public, and governmental spheres. The SPF protects the rights of small and middle-sized businesses. Its persistent concern is the problems faced by recipients of welfare. The SPF will seek to achieve its goals only by peaceful, political means, respecting the [[Constitution of Lithuania]], laws, and international acts and principles that defend human rights.}} ==Structure== The SPF congress is the supreme organ of the party. The congress chooses the party's executive council, which oversees and organizes the activity of the party in between congresses, received decisions regarding creating coalitions with other parties, and approves the budget, any reports on the use of funds, and the candidacy of the head of the election committee. The party's sole leader is the chairperson. Territorial subgroups of the party are its chapters and groups. == Participation in elections == The party participated in [[Lithuanian parliamentary election, 2012|Parliamentary elections]] and came 11th with 16,515 (1.21%) votes and no seats. The municipal elections in 2015 were more successful, as the political block the party participated in received 68 seats, of which 2 were delegates of SPF, including [[Rafael Muksinov]], a current member of [[Vilnius City Council]]. The party council decided not to participate in [[Lithuanian parliamentary election, 2016|the parliamentary election in 2016]]. ==Controversies== The SPF caused controversy twice in 2010 when members of the party were denied entry into [[Estonia]]. On April 21, party leader Algirdas Paleckis was part of a group of activists traveling to Estonia to protest [[NATO]]'s policy regarding the [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|war in Afghanistan]]. Paleckis was told that he was on the Estonian [[persona non-grata]] list because of his political views and activities.[http://www.alfa.lt/straipsnis/10352825/?Lithuanian.radical.denied.entry.to.Estonia=2010-04-22_08-26 Lithuanian radical denied entry into Estonia] [[Baltic News Service|BNS]]/alfa.lt article retrieved August 27, 2010. In late June, SPF activists, along with [[anti-fascism|anti-fascists]] from [[Latvia]], were denied entry on their way to protest a meeting of veterans of the [[20th Waffen Grenadier Division of the SS (1st Estonian)|20th Waffen Grenadier Division of the SS]] near the [[Vaivara concentration camp]].[http://www.interfax.com/newsinf.asp?id=180496 Lithuanian, Latvian antifascists barred from entering Estonia to protest congress of SS veterans] [[Interfax]] article retrieved August 27, 2010. The activists were told that their vehicle was not fit for entry, and, according to the SPF, the only member of the SPF who managed the border crossing into Estonia was not on the official SPF list of activists and had not been mentioned by name by protest organizers over the telephone.[http://fronte.lt/index.php?lng=lt&action=page&id=3631 EXTRA :Saugant buvusių SSinkų ir jų gerbėjų ramybę. Neįleisti SLF ir kitų antifašistinių judėjimų nariai.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722150540/http://fronte.lt/index.php?lng=lt&action=page&id=3631 |date=July 22, 2011 }} SLF Info article in [[Lithuanian language|Lithuanian]] retrieved August 27, 2010. In 2011, Lithuanian authorities had initiated prosecution against Paleckis for his denial of [[Occupation of the Baltic states|Soviet aggression against Lithuania]],http://press.org/news-multimedia/news/lithuanian-former-journalist-accuses-country-trying-deny-his-speech-freedom-sen/ or, to be more specific, against his claim that Soviet soldiers and special units were not responsible for the deaths of 14 people (including one victim of [[friendly fire]]) in January 13, 1991.https://www.15min.lt/en/article/in-lithuania/algirdas-paleckis-found-guilty-of-denying-soviet-aggression-525-225836 Paleckis allegedly found several witnesses and ballistic assessments that seemed to indicate that there were secret snipers on the roof of the Vilnius TV centre who were shooting into the civilians. He then went on to state publicly that "it appears that in January 1991 our own people were shooting at our own people."{{cite news|title=Algirdas Paleckis, or a new Dreyfus case in Europe?|url=http://www.regnum.ru/english/1534153.html|newspaper=REGNUM news}} It was the first verdict in Lithuania's history on charges of denying aggressive conduct of the Soviet Union.[https://www.15min.lt/en/article/in-lithuania/algirdas-paleckis-found-guilty-of-denying-soviet-aggression-525-225836] A [[Vilnius]] court had vindicated Paleckis in January 2012. The prosecution had appealed, and Paleckis was sentenced to a fine of 10,400 [[litas]] on June 12, 2012.https://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/dpb/2012/08/196986.htm Paleckis himself claimed that there was purportedly no independent investigation into the events of January 13, 1991 at the Vilnius TV tower. The party also hails the Constitution of [[People's Seimas]], adopted by the [[puppet government]] led by [[Justas Paleckis]]. During the demonstration to commemorate Independence Day of Lithuania on February 15, 2014, the leader of Kaunas' branch [[Giedrius Grabauskas]] commented on the [[Act of the Re-Establishment of the State of Lithuania|Act of March 11]] as the one "having brought severe consequences to Lithuania".[http://www.lrytas.lt/lietuvos-diena/aktualijos/paleckininkus-suerzino-smaiksus-studentu-plakatai.htm Paleckininkus suerzino šmaikšūs studentų plakatai] During the events of [[EuroMaidan]] the party was one of very few in Lithuania who clearly expressed support for a then-president [[Viktor Yanukovych]]. In May 20, 2014 the party, together with other small radical organisations, organised a small rally in front of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to voice its opposition towards Lithuanian foreign policy during the Russia-Ukraine conflict, making accusations for "representing the interests of the US and EU, not Lithuanian ones". A former leader [[Algirdas Paleckis]] left the party in January 2016, just before the Parliamentary election. He motivated such a decision by "diverted opinions with the party leadership", their "overestimation of the significance of rallies and underestimation of the one of participation in the election". As a result, Paleckis participated in the election as an independent candidate in [[Naujoji Vilnia]].[https://www.15min.lt/naujiena/aktualu/lietuva/algirdas-paleckis-palieka-fronta-56-570607] The party with a new leadership started to use more [[left-wing nationalism|nationalist]] rhetoric. ==Political positions== Even though the party is economically [[far-left]], with the statements often attacking [[free market economics]], it has voiced its ultra-[[Conservatism]] in issues, such as [[LGBT rights]] and [[immigration policy]]. One of its members [[Sergejus Sokolovas]] in its interview declared that leftists should fight sexual minorities rather than support them. He also referred to the supporters of [[LGBT movement]] as ''[[tolerasts]]'', a pun of [[Toleration|tolerance]] and [[paederasty]] frequently used by the hate speech groups.[http://www.anarchija.lt/politika/34269-socialistinis-liaudies-frontas-pasisako-uz-konservatyvias-vertybes-ir-konservatyvia-seimos-samprata „Socialistinis“ liaudies frontas pasisako už konservatyvias vertybes ir konservatyvią šeimos sampratą] Its former leader [[Algirdas Paleckis]] would be among the initiators for organising the [[Lithuanian land sales referendum, 2014|referendum on banning land sales to foreigners]]. The party also opposes quotas for [[refugees]] and participated in an anti-refugee rally held in [[Šiauliai]] in November 14, 2015. Other than [[European refugee crisis]] that they referred to as a 'involuntary immigration', the rally also highlighted "human rights abuses of the working class", "war propaganda" and "[[Russophobia]]". The demonstration also saw the attendance of a [[political syncretism|syncretic]] sister organisation "The Combat", as well as [[Way of Courage]] and right-wing populist [[Fighters for Lithuania Union]], former neo-Nazi activist [[Žilvinas Razminas]].[http://www.laisvaslaikrastis.lt/news/1035-siauliuose-ivyko-patriotinis-mitingas-priverstinei-imigracijai-ne-darbo-zmoniu-teisems-taip] ==Leadership== *[[Algirdas Paleckis]] (2009-2014) *[[Edikas Jagelavičius]] (2014-2017) *[[Giedrius Grabauskas]] (2017-) ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.slfrontas.lt slfrontas.lt] Official site {{Lithuanian political parties}} [[Category:Communist parties in Lithuania]] [[Category:Political parties established in 2009]] [[Category:2009 establishments in Lithuania]] [[Category:Socialist parties in Lithuania]] [[Category:Organizations that oppose LGBT rights]]

"'''Super recognisers'''" is a term coined in 2009 by [[Harvard University|Harvard]] and [[University College London]] researchers for people with significantly better-than-average [[Face perception|face recognition]] ability.<ref>Russell R, Duchaine B, Nakayama K Super-recognizers: People with extraordinary face recognition ability ''[[Psychonomic Bulletin & Review]]'' Apr 2009 Vol 16(2) Pages 252-7</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thecut.com/2016/06/are-you-a-super-recognizer.html|title=Are You Any Good at Recognizing Familiar Faces? Here, Test Yourself|last=Dahl|first=Melissa|work=The Cut|access-date=2018-09-27|language=en}}</ref> Super recognisers are able to memorise and recall thousands of faces, often having seen them only once.<ref name="guardian-moshakis">{{cite web|first1=Alex|last1=Moshakis|accessdate=2018-11-13|title=Super recognisers: the people who never forget a face|url=http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/nov/11/super-recognisers-police-the-people-who-never-forget-a-face|date=11 November 2018|website=The Guardian}}</ref>
The skill is recognised and employed among the British intelligence community.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.crimeandinvestigation.co.uk/article/super-recognisers|title=Super Recognisers|date=2017-07-05|work=Crime + Investigation|access-date=2018-09-27|language=en}}</ref> It is the extreme opposite of [[prosopagnosia]]. It is estimated that 1 to 2% of the population are super recognisers<ref name="guardian-moshakis"/> who can remember 80% of faces they have seen.<ref>Zolfagharifard E [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3125173/Are-super-recogniser-test-one-elite-group-people-rarely-forgets-face.html Are YOU a 'super recogniser'? Take the test to see if you are one of an elite group of people who never forget a face] ''[[Daily Mail]]'' 16 Jun 2015</ref>{{rs|date=September 2018}} Most people can only remember about 20% of faces. They can match faces better than [[Face detection|computer recognition]] systems in some circumstances.<ref name="guardian-moshakis"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/05/world/europe/salisbury-novichok-poisoning.html|title=From Mountain of CCTV Footage, Pay Dirt: 2 Russians Are Named in Spy Poisoning|publisher=|accessdate=6 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2016/08/22/londons-super-recognizer-police-force|title=The Detectives Who Never Forget a Face|publisher=|accessdate=6 September 2018}}</ref> The science behind this is poorly understood but may be related to the [[fusiform face area]] part of the brain.<ref name="guardian-moshakis"/>
In May 2015,<ref>Hamill J [https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/1955059/metropolitan-police-super-recognisers-have-busted-thousands-of-criminals/ Metropolitan Police 'super-recognisers' have busted THOUSANDS of criminals] ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' 11 Oct 2016</ref> the [[Metropolitan Police Service|London Metropolitan Police]] officially formed a team made up of people with this heightened capability for recognising people and put them to work identifying individuals whose faces are captured on [[CCTV]].<ref name="guardian-moshakis"/> [[Scotland Yard]] has a squad of over 200 super recognisers.{{cn|date=September 2018}} In August 2018, it was reported that the Metropolitan Police had used two super recognisers to identify the suspects of the attack on [[Poisoning of Sergei and Yulia Skripal|Sergei and Yulia Skripal]], after trawling through up to 5,000 hours of CCTV footage from [[Salisbury]] and numerous airports across the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/aug/06/uk-poised-to-ask-russia-to-extradite-salisbury-attack-suspects|title=UK poised to ask Russia to extradite Salisbury attack suspects|first1=Nick|last1=Hopkins|first2=Luke|last2=Harding|first3=Ewen|last3=MacAskill|date=6 August 2018|website=the Guardian}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.sky.com/story/super-recognisers-help-identify-skripal-suspects-11483995|title=Super recogniser squad tracks Skripal novichok attackers|publisher=}}</ref> __NOTOC__
==Glasgow Face Matching Test== Super recognisers performed well in the [[Glasgow Face Matching Test]] in comparison with a control group.<ref>Robertson DJ [https://theconversation.com/could-super-recognisers-be-the-latest-weapon-in-the-war-on-terror-56772 Could super recognisers be the latest weapon on the war on terror?] ''[[The Conversation]]'' 24 Mar 2016</ref>

You might be a super recogniser] ''[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]'' 27 Sep 2016 * Rice X [http://www.newstatesman.com/politics/uk/2016/08/super-recognisers-scotland-yard The super-recognisers of Scotland Yard] ''[[New Statesman]]'' 2 August 2016 * [http://www.itv.com/news/london/2016-08-26/police-to-deploy-super-recognisers-to-scan-cctv-to-pick-out-offenders-and-trouble-makers-at-notting-hill-carnival/ Police to deploy 'super-recognisers' to scan CCTV to pick out offenders and trouble makers at Notting Hill Carnival] ''[[ITV News]]'' 26 Aug 2016

'''Surveillance abuse''' is the use of [[surveillance]] methods or technology to monitor the activity of an individual or group of individuals in a way which violates the social [[norm (sociology)|norms]] or laws of a society.
During the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]]'s [[COINTELPRO]] operations, there was widespread surveillance abuse which targeted political [[dissident]]s, primarily people from the [[Left-wing politics|political left]] and [[civil rights]] movement.
Other abuses include "[[LOVEINT]]" which refers to the practice of secret service employees using their extensive monitoring capabilities to spy on their love interest or spouse.<ref>{{cite web |title=NSA Officers Spy on Love Interests |url=https://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2013/08/23/nsa-officers-sometimes-spy-on-love-interests/}}</ref>
There is no prevention in the amount of unauthorized data collected on individuals and this leads to cases where cameras are installed inappropriately. “For instance, according to the [[BBC]], four council workers in [[Liverpool]] used a street [[Closed-circuit television|CCTV]] pan-tilt-zoom camera to spy on a woman in her apartment.” (Cavallaro,2007). This is just one case where culprits have been caught; however, there are still many common acts such as this. Another incident of inappropriate installation now has “[[Pennsylvania]] parents suing their son's school, alleging it watched him through his laptop's webcam while he was at home and unaware he was being observed.” (Surveillance Camera Players, 2010). This leads to the misconception of surveillance, as it once was a tool to monitor and make sure citizens abide by the law, it has now created even more problems. With cameras only becoming more advanced and more common, it is difficult to determine whether these surveillance cameras are helping to ensure a safe society or leading to bigger issues altogether.
With the growing of [[Web 2.0]], social networking sites, surveillance may be more easily and commonly abused in many situations for a variety of reasons. The Communications Security Establishment (CSE), formerly known as [[Communications Security Establishment|Communications Security Establishment Canada]] (CSEC), has previously spied on Canadians through the public wireless internet connections in an airport in the country. Through this they gathered information on who people called or texted and where they were when they communicated with others. The CSE search through approximately 10-15 million downloads daily. An example of where surveillance may have been abused is where [[Facebook]] and [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] have admitted to allowing government officials to access personal information of their account users. <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://torontosun.com/2013/07/08/how-the-canadian-government-can-spy-on-your-online-activities/wcm/8fe99b8a-2172-48ee-b2dc-5f8704916b42|title=How the Canadian Government Can Spy on Your Online Activities|last=Alexander|first=Julia|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://liberalstudiesguides.ca/guides/little-brother/brown-where-is-canadas-rage-over-digital-surveillance/|title=Where Is Canada's Rage over Digital Surveillance?|last=Brown|first=Jesse|date=2014|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/cse-monitors-millions-of-canadian-emails-to-government-1.2969687|title=CSE Monitors Millions of Canadian Emails to Government|last=Hildebrant, Ambera; Dave Seglins and Michael Pereira|first=|date=2015|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lievrouw|first=Leah A.|date=2011|title=Alternative and Activist New Media|url=|journal=Cambridge, UK: Polity|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
A device which may be used to abuse surveillance, called a [[Stingray phone tracker|Stingray]], acts and looks similar to a cellphone tower but it tricks mobile devices into connecting with it. After connected an operator can take information stored on the device, sometimes intercepting phone calls and text messages. This method of surveillance can be used on random civilians or in an investigation of a particular person.<ref>Braga, Matthew. "The Covert Cellphone Tracking Tech the RCMP and CSIS Won't Talk about." ''The Globe and Mail''. N.p., 15 Sept. 2014. Web. 28 Oct. 2015.</ref>

{{Multiple issues|section=| {{cleanup|reason=possible POV and advertising issues|date=September 2014}} {{Refimprove|date=April 2018}} }} '''Sustainable diets''' are defined as "those diets with low environmental impacts that contribute to food and nutritional security and to healthy lives for present and future generations. Sustainable diets are protective and respectful of biodiversity and ecosystems, culturally acceptable, accessible, economically fair and affordable, are nutritionally adequate, safe, and healthy, and optimize natural and human resources."Barbara Burlingame and Sandro Dernini (2012). “Sustainable Diets and Biodiversity Directions and Solutions for Policy, Research and Action.” Proceedings of the International Scientific Symposium, ''Biodiversity and Sustainable Diets against Hunger'', November 3-5, 2010, FAO Headquarters, Rome These diets attempt to address undernourishment, nutrient deficiencies and obesity and covers ecological phenomena such as [[climate change]], [[loss of biodiversity]] and [[land degradation]].Tara Garnett, "What is a sustainable healthy diet? A discussion paper," Food Climate Research Network, April 2014. Retrieved 25 October 2018 from https://www.fcrn.org.uk/sites/default/files/fcrn_what_is_a_sustainable_healthy_diet_final.pdf As a theme, it also covers the study of eating patterns that look at the impact that food consumption has on planetary resources and the health of humans and promotes the needs of the environment, society, and the economy. This growing body of research is recognized by a variety of international bodies such as the [[United Nations]] [[Food and Agriculture Organization]] (FAO) and the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO). ==Definition == In 2010, the FAO and [[Bioversity International]] defined a sustainable diet as:
those diets with low environmental impacts which contribute to food and nutrition security and to healthy life for present and future generations. Sustainable diets are protective and respectful of biodiversity and ecosystems, culturally acceptable, accessible, economically fair and affordable; nutritionally adequate, safe and healthy; while optimizing natural and human resources.FAO. 2012. [http://www.fao.org/docrep/016/i3004e/i3004e.pdf ''Sustainable Diets and Biodiversity: Directions and Solutions for Policy, Research and Action'']. [Accessed 13 January 2013]
== Diets denominated as "sustainable" == Sustainable diets mostly concentrate on issues that have something to do with Low Carbon Diets which are structured to reduce the impact of global warming.{{Cite news|url=http://www.bamco.com/timeline/low-carbon-diet/|title=Low Carbon Diet - Bon Appétit Management Co.|last=Company|first=Bon Appétit Management|work=Bon Appétit Management Co.|access-date=2017-03-05|language=en-US}} Others also focus on broader environmental factors, as well as social and economic challenges. Other regionalized diets include the [[Mediterranean diet]]{{Cite journal|url=http://www.bioversityinternational.org/e-library/publications/detail/sustainability-and-food-and-nutrition-security-a-vulnerability-assessment-framework-for-the-mediter/ |doi= 10.1177/2158244014539169|title= Sustainability and Food & Nutrition Security|journal= SAGE Open|volume= 4|issue= 2|pages= 215824401453916|year= 2014|last1= Prosperi|first1= Paolo|last2= Allen|first2= Thomas|last3= Padilla|first3= Martine|last4= Peri|first4= Iuri|last5= Cogill|first5= Bruce}} and the [[Nordic diet]] which emphasizes the consumption of local foodstuffs."[http://www.listnutrition.com/what-is-the-nordic-diet/ What is the Nordic Diet?]" Retrieved 16 February 2015 ==Common alternative diets== * [[Economic vegetarianism]] * [[Environmental vegetarianism]] * [[Fruitarianism]] * [[Sattvic diet]] * [[Veganism]] * [[Vegetarianism]] ==See also== {{div col}} * [[Biodiversity and food]] * [[Cultured meat]] * [[Environmental impact of meat production]] * [[Environmentalism]] * [[Ethical eating]] * [[Ethics of eating meat]] * [[Organic farming]] * [[Organic food]] * [[Organic gardening]] * [[Stock-free agriculture]] * [[Sustainable agriculture]] * [[Sustainable food system]] * [[Forest gardening]] * [[Vegan organic gardening]] {{div col end}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Portal bar|Food}} [[Category:Diets]] [[Category:Environmental impact of agriculture]] [[Category:Food and the environment]] [[Category:Sustainable food system]] [[Category:Vegetarianism]]

140,000 dead.Sennikov, B.V. (2004). [http://rusk.ru/vst.php?idar=321701 ''Tambov rebellion and liquidation of peasants in Russia'']. Moscow: Posev. In Russian. {{ISBN|5-85824-152-2}} |casualties1= |casualties2= |}} {{Campaignbox Russian Civil War}} {{Southern Front of the Russian Civil War}} The '''Tambov Rebellion''' (historically referred to in the Soviet Union as ''Antonovshchina''), which occurred between 1920 and 1921, was one of the largest and best-organized [[List of peasant revolts|peasant rebellion]]s challenging the [[Bolshevik]] regime during the [[Russian Civil War]].[[Robert Conquest]], ''[[The Harvest of Sorrow]]: Soviet Collectivization and the Terror-Famine'', [[Oxford University Press]], New York, 1986, {{ISBN|0-19-504054-6}}.Nicolas Werth, Karel Bartošek, Jean-Louis Panné, Jean-Louis Margolin, Andrzej Paczkowski, [[Stéphane Courtois]], ''[[The Black Book of Communism]]: Crimes, Terror, Repression'', [[Harvard University Press]], 1999, hardcover, 858 pages, {{ISBN|0-674-07608-7}}. The uprising took place in the territories of the modern [[Tambov Oblast]] and part of the [[Voronezh Oblast]], less than 300 miles southeast of Moscow. In [[Historiography in the Soviet Union|Soviet historiography]], the rebellion was referred to as the "Antonov's mutiny", or ''Antonovschina'', named so after [[Alexander Antonov (politician)|Alexander Antonov]], a former official of the [[Socialist Revolutionary Party]], a [[Chief of staff]] of the rebels. The movement was later portrayed by the Soviets as anarchical banditry, similar to other [[Left-wing uprisings against the Bolsheviks|anti-Soviet movements]] that opposed them during this period. == Background == [[File:1920 staff tambov green army.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Alexander Antonov (politician)|Alexander Antonov]] (centre) and his staff]] The rebellion was caused by the forced confiscation of grain by the [[Bolshevik]] authorities, a policy known in Russian as "''[[prodrazvyorstka]]''". In 1920, the requisitions were increased from 18 million to 27 million [[pood]]s in the region. This caused the peasants to reduce their grain production since they knew that anything they did not consume themselves would be immediately confiscated. Filling the state quotas meant death for many by starvation. The revolt began on 19 August 1920 in a small town of Khitrovo, where a military requisitioning detachment of the [[Red Army]] appropriated everything they could and "beat up elderly men of seventy in full view of the public". A distinctive feature of this rebellion, among the many of these times, was that it was led by a political organization, the [[Union of Working Peasants]] (''Soyuz Trudovogo Krestyanstva''). A Congress of Tambov rebels abolished Soviet power and created the Constituent Assembly that called for universal suffrage and land reform. A major tenet proposed by them was returning all land to the peasants. On 2 February 1921, the Soviet leadership announced the end of the "''prodrazvyorstka''", and issued a special decree directed at peasants from the region implementing the "''[[prodnalog]]''" policy. The new policy was essentially a tax on grain and other foodstuffs. This was done prior to the [[10th Congress of the Russian Communist Party (Bolsheviks)|10th Congress]] of the Bolsheviks, when the measure was officially adopted. The announcement began circulating in the Tambov area on 9 February 1921. The Tambov uprising and unrest elsewhere were significant reasons that the "''prodnalog''" policy was implemented and the "''prodrazvyorstka''" was abandoned.Landis, 2004. ==Timeline== [[Alexander Antonov (politician)|Alexander Antonov]], a radical member of the [[Left Socialist Revolutionaries]], had sided with the Bolsheviks during the [[Russian Revolution]] in 1917, but he became disenchanted with them after they implemented a [[Prodrazvyorstka|policy of grain requisition]] in 1918. Antonov became a popular hero to the people of the [[Tambov]] region of central Russia where he started his campaigns. In October 1920 the peasant army numbered over 50,000 fighters; numerous deserters from the Red Army joined it. The rebel militia proved highly effective and even infiltrated the Tambov [[Cheka]]. [[Alexander Schlichter]], Chairman of the [[Tambov Oblast|Tambov]] Gubernia Executive Committee, contacted [[Vladimir Lenin]], who ordered Red Army reinforcements to the area.[http://marxists.org/archive/lenin/works//1920/oct/19c.htm Lenin to Kornev, 19 October, 1920]. Accessed 21 June 2017. In January 1921 peasant revolts spread to [[Samara, Russia|Samara]], [[Saratov]], [[Volgograd|Tsaritsyn]], [[Astrakhan]] and [[Siberia]]. In February, the peasant army reached its peak, numbering up to 70,000 and successfully defending the area against Bolshevik expeditions. The seriousness of the uprising caused the establishment of the "Plenipotentiary Commission of the All-Russian Central Executive Committee of the Bolshevik Party for the Liquidation of Banditry in the Gubernia of Tambov". With the end of the [[Polish–Soviet War]] (in March 1921) and the defeat of [[Pyotr Nikolayevich Wrangel|General Wrangel]] in 1920, the Red Army could divert its regular troops into the area - deploying in total over 100,000 Red Army soldiers, alongside special Cheka detachments. The Red Army, under the command of [[Mikhail Tukhachevsky]], used heavy artillery and [[armoured train]]s and also engaged in the summary execution of civilians. Tukhachevsky and [[Vladimir Antonov-Ovseyenko]] signed an order, dated 12 June 1921, which stipulated: {{Quotation|1="The forests where the bandits are hiding are to be cleared by the use of poison gas. This must be carefully calculated, so that the layer of gas penetrates the forests and kills everyone hiding there."}} The Bolshevik forces used [[chemical weapon]]s "from end of June 1921 until apparently the fall of 1921", by direct order from the leadership of Red Army and from the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union|Communist Party]].Publisher: Posev, 2004, {{ISBN|5-85824-152-2}} [http://www.rusk.ru/vst.php?idar=321701 B.V.Sennikov. ''Tambov rebellion and liquidation of peasants in Russia''], Full text in Russian Publications in local Communist newspapers openly glorified liquidations of "bandits" with the poison gas. Seven [[Internment|concentration camp]]s were set up. At least 50,000 people were interned, mostly women, children, and the elderly - some of them sent to the camps as hostages. Each month 5 percent of inmates in the camps died. The Bolsheviks gradually quelled the uprising in the course of 1921. Antonov was killed in 1922 during an attempt to arrest him. Sennikov estimated the total losses among the population of Tambov region in 1920 to 1922 resulting from the war, executions, and imprisonment in concentration camps as approximately 140,000. {{cite book | last1 = Sennikov | first1 = Boris V. | title = Тамбовское восстание 1918-1921 гг. и раскрестьянивание России 1929-1933гг.: "Тамбовская Вандея" |trans-title=The Tambov uprising of 1918 to 1921 and the de-peasantisation of Russia of 1929 to 1933: "The Tambov Vendee" | url = http://rusk.ru/vst.php?idar=321701 | series = Серия "Библиотечка россиеведения" | language = Russian | issue = 9 | location = Moscow | publisher = Посев | publication-date = 2004 | isbn = 5-85824-152-2 | accessdate = 2015-11-12 | quote = Во всяком случае, по самым осторожным подсчетам, потери населения Тамбовской губернии в 1920-1922 гг. составили около 240 тыс. человек. [In any case, according to the most careful reckoning, the losses of the residents of the Tambov Governorate in the years 1920 to 1922 amounted to approximately 240 thousand persons.] }} ==Recovery of documents== Some documents relating to the rebellion were found by the local ethnographer Boris Sennikov in 1982 while he was engaged in clearing sand from the altar of the Winter Church of the Kazan monastery.[http://gulag.ipvnews.org/article20061017.php An illustrated article about Tambov revolt from Gulag website (Russian)] During the 1920s, the monastery had been requisitioned for use as the local Cheka headquarters and the church had served as the archive of the Tambov Military Commissariat. In 1933, the local government decided to burn documents that could compromise the Soviet regime. However, during the process, the fire grew out of control and had to be extinguished by water and, crucially, sand. All documents in the archive were believed to be destroyed; as the church altar was not used by the archive, the surviving documents, covered by a layer of sand, had never been found. In 1982, the local archive changed its address and the church became abandoned. When Sennikov found the documents, the Tambov department of [[KGB]] opened a criminal case against him. Later, the case was closed, but Sennikov lost his job. In 2004, the publishing house ''Posev'' published the Sennikov archive as part of ''The Tambov Rebellion and the Liquidation of Russian Peasantry'' along with documents relating to the Governorate Military Commissariat (including those dealing with [[Konstantin Mamontov]]'s 1919 anti-Bolshevik raid, and those describing the [[Great Purge]] of the 1930s). The documents also included Red Army orders issued during the rebellion, correspondence, reports of the use of chemical weapons against the peasant rebels, and documents of the Union of the Working Peasants. ==In popular culture== * Some scenes of the rebellion are depicted in 2011 movie ''[[Once Upon a Time There Lived a Simple Woman]]'' by [[Andrei Smirnov (actor)|Andrei Smirnov]]. * ''Apricot Jam and Other Stories'' (2010) by [[Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn]]. In a short story about Marshal [[Georgy Zhukov]]'s futile attempts at writing his memoirs, the retired Marshal reminisces about being a young officer fighting against the [[Union of Working Peasants]]. He recalls [[Mikhail Tukhachevsky]]'s arrival to take command of the campaign and his first address to his men. He announced that [[total war]] and [[scorched earth]] tactics are to be used against civilians who assist or even sympathize with the Union. Zhukov proudly recalls how Tukhachevsky's tactics were adopted and succeeded in breaking the uprising.
